fullText: Photograph: Courtesy Marc J. Franklin | Hell‚Äôs KitchenReviewHell's Kitchen4 out of 5 starsA new Broadway musical offers Keys to the city.Theater, MusicalsShubert Theatre, Midtown WestOpen runRecommendedSaturday April 20 2024ShareCopy LinkFacebookTwitterPinterestEmailWhatsAppBuy ticketWritten by Adam FeldmanTheater and Dance Editor, Time Out USAAdvertising window.rawSlots = window.rawSlots || []; window.rawSlots.push('{"adSlotId":"/5185/body1/event","adContainerId":"ad-body-1-3792","isOutOfPage":false,"isRegistered":false,"adSizes":[{"viewport":[992,50],"slotSize":[]},{"viewport":[320,50],"slotSize":[[1,1],[320,100],[320,50],[300,600],[300,250],[300,100],[300,50]]},{"viewport":[0,0],"slotSize":[]}],"prebidSizes":[{"minViewPort":[800,0],"sizes":[[728,90]]},{"minViewPort":[320,50],"sizes":[[320,100],[320,50],[300,600],[300,250],[300,100],[300,50]]},{"minViewPort":[320,0],"sizes":[[320,100],[320,50],[300,250],[300,100],[300,50]]},{"minViewPort":[0,0],"sizes":[]}],"adTags":[{"key":"type","value":"body1"},{"key":"ad_slot_number","value":"ad-body-1"},{"key":"refresh","value":"30"}],"adSenseTags":[],"adSlotGroup":"body","breakpoints":["xs","sm"],"loadsAutomatically":true}'); Time Out says Broadway review by Adam Feldman Hell‚Äôs Kitchen, whose score is drawn from the pop catalog of Alicia Keys, could easily have gone down in flames. Jukebox musicals often do; songs that sound great on the radio can‚Äôt always pull their weight onstage. But playwright Kristoffer Diaz, director Michael Greif and choreographer Camille A. Brown have found the right recipe for this show‚Äîand, in its vivid dancers and magnificent singers, just the right ingredients‚Äîand they've cooked up a heck of a block party. window.rawSlots = window.rawSlots || []; window.rawSlots.push('{"adSlotId":"/5185/outstream/event","adContainerId":"ad-outstream-1-6593","isOutOfPage":false,"isRegistered":false,"adSizes":[{"viewport":[320,50],"slotSize":[[1,1],"fluid"]},{"viewport":[0,0],"slotSize":[]}],"prebidSizes":[{"minViewPort":[320,0],"sizes":[[1,1],[640,360],[400,250]]},{"minViewPort":[0,0],"sizes":[]}],"adTags":[{"key":"type","value":"inline"},{"key":"ad_slot_number","value":"ad-outstream-1"}],"adSenseTags":[],"adSlotGroup":"outstream","breakpoints":[],"loadsAutomatically":true}'); Inspired by Keys‚Äôs life, Hell‚Äôs Kitchen has the sensibly narrow scope of a short story. Newcomer Maleah Joi Moon‚Äîin a stunningly assured debut‚Äîplays Ali, a beautiful but directionless mixed-race teenager growing up in midtown‚Äôs artist-friendly Manhattan Plaza in the 1990s, a period conjured winsomely and wittily by Dede Ayite‚Äôs costumes. The issues Ali faces are realistic ones: tensions with her protective single mother, Jersey (Shoshana Bean); disappointment with the charming musician father, Davis (Brandon Victor Dixon), who yo-yos in and out of their lives; a crush on a thicc, slightly older street drummer, Knuck (Chris Lee); a desire to impress a stately pianist, Miss Liza Jane (Kecia Lewis), who lives in the building. Hell‚Äôs Kitchen | Photograph: Courtesy Marc J. Franklin The show‚Äôs chain of Keys songs is its most obvious selling point, but it could also have been a limitation. Musically, the tunes are not built for drama‚Äîthey tend to sit in a leisurely R&B groove‚Äîand the lyrics, while effective, are not especially inventive or rigorous. (Describing New York City as a ‚Äúconcrete jungle where dreams are made of [sic]‚Äù is careless enough writing to make a person [sic]). What they do deliver is a vibe, and Greif‚Äôs production rides it smartly. It lets the songs set a general tone while clear acting beats take care of the specifics; the characters relate around the songs as much as through them. And Diaz rolls out Keys‚Äôs oeuvre in a way that complements his coming-of-age narrative. Hell‚Äôs Kitchen‚Äôs first half is constructed around relatively unfamiliar material, including a few new songs written for the show. ‚ÄúGirl on Fire‚Äù flares up toward the end of the first act in a number led by Ali‚Äôs friends Tiny (an ebullient Vanessa Ferguson) and Jessica (Jackie Leon), the Bess and George to her Nancy Drew; but otherwise, the biggest Keys hits‚Äîincluding ‚ÄúFallin‚Äô,‚Äù ‚ÄúIf I Ain‚Äôt Got You‚Äù and ‚ÄúNo One‚Äù‚Äîare saved for after intermission, as though to reinforce our sense of Ali‚Äôs growing confidence and maturity. We don‚Äôt need much convincing on that front. With apologies to astronomers: Moon is a star. Beneath Ali‚Äôs failed efforts to look cool are a mess of strong feelings‚Äîshe‚Äôs at an age where everything seems important‚Äîbut beneath those strong feelings is the actual cool of a young performer with the self-possession to own a Broadway stage. And Moon‚Äôs unforced, distinctively breathy voice sits perfectly between those of her two maternal figures in the show. Below her is Lewis‚Äôs cavernous contralto; when Miss Liza Jane closes the first act with a shattering ‚ÄúPerfect Way to Die,‚Äù a song about police violence, it‚Äôs like the earth itself is rising up in pain. And above her is the muscular mix of Bean‚Äôs high belt, which she flexes in a furious musical tirade, ‚ÄúPawn It All,‚Äù whose staggeringly precise runs stop the show cold. Dixon‚Äôs vocals, meanwhile, help explain why people keep falling for Davis; at least he sounds like an angel. (Garth Owen‚Äôs sound design gives all of these remarkable singers the support they deserve.) Hell‚Äôs Kitchen | Photograph: Courtesy Marc J. Franklin As its title suggests, Hell‚Äôs Kitchen extends its attention to the neighborhood beyond the central story. The fire escapes and signage of Robert Brills‚Äôs scenic design and Perter Nigrini‚Äôs projections, augmented by the dazzle of Natasha Katz‚Äôs lighting, help set the urban scene. But the most important factor is Brown‚Äôs outstanding choreography: Executed gorgeously by an ensemble that includes several dancers she has worked with in the past, the show‚Äôs bold and graceful movement summons a world of kinetic energy for Ali to tap into when she is finally able to organize her talent. When Hell‚Äôs Kitchen inevitably concludes with ‚ÄúEmpire State of Mind,‚Äù the song doesn‚Äôt feel tacked on, because New York has been keenly felt throughout the show. It may touch on social issues of consequence, but Hell‚Äôs Kitchen is ultimately a celebration of the city‚Äîand the people who make it pop. Hell‚Äôs Kitchen. Shubert Theater (Broadway). Music and lyrics by Alicia Keys. Book by Kristoffer Diaz. Directed by Michael Greif. With Maleah Joi Moon, Shoshana Bean, Kecia Lewis, Brandon Victor Dixon, Chris Lee, Vanessa Ferguson, Jackie Leon. Running time: 2hrs 30mins. One intermission. Follow Adam Feldman on X: @FeldmanAdamFollow Time Out Theater on X: @TimeOutTheaterKeep up with the latest news and reviews on our Time Out Theater Facebook page Hell‚Äôs Kitchen | Photograph: Courtesy Marc J.
